metadata.case_name: Union of India v. H. Goel

facts.text: Respondent H. Goel joined Central Public Works Department on 26th November 1941, selected for Class I post in 1945-46.
In January 1956, posted as Surveyor of Works at Calcutta, made representation to Union Public Service Commission regarding seniority.
Respondent went to Delhi mid-January 1956, called on Mr. R. Rajagopalan (Deputy Director of Administration) at residence on 19th January 1956 to discuss representation.
During conversation, respondent allegedly apologised for not having brought rasagullas for Mr. Rajagopalan's children; Mr. Rajagopalan expressed displeasure.
Respondent allegedly took out wallet, produced folded hundred rupee note; Mr. Rajagopalan disapproved, respondent put it back.
Mr. Rajagopalan reported incident to Mr. Ananthakrishnan, submitted written complaint adding respondent asked to meet next day.

Appellant suspended respondent, served notice on 9th February 1956 with four charges: (1) Meeting without permission, (2) Expressing regret for not bringing sweets, (3) Offering 100 rupee note as bribe, (4) Violation of Rule 3 CCS Conduct Rules.
Enquiry under Rule 55 by Mr. Kapoor; examined witnesses, report on 10th April 1956 that charges not satisfactorily proved.
Appellant considered report, issued second notice on 14th June 1956 proposing dismissal.
UPSC report 30th October 1956: drop charge 1, charge 2 not justifying action, charge 3 not proved, charge 4 fails; no penalty under Rule 49.
Appellant remitted to UPSC on 8th December 1956; UPSC reaffirmed on 15th January 1957.
Appellant dismissed respondent by order on 13th March 1957.
Respondent filed writ petition No. 201-D of 1957 in Punjab High Court under Arts 226 and 311; single judge dismissed.
Letters Patent Appeal No. 27-D of 1959 allowed by Division Bench on 2nd August 1960; held govt could not differ from enquiry officer, quashed dismissal.
Appellant obtained special leave, present appeal.
Mr. Rajagopalan admitted note folded double, blue colour, bigger size; could not say offered as bribe; eyesight not perfect.
Respondent said took out papers for appointment letter, put back when discouraged.

legal_issues.text: Whether Government is competent to differ from the findings of fact recorded by the enquiry officer under Rule 55 of the Civil Services Rules.
Whether the High Court in a writ petition is entitled to hold that the conclusion reached by the Government in regard to misconduct is not supported by any evidence at all.

petitioner_arguments.text: Government is competent to differ from enquiry officer's findings, as enquiry officer acts as delegate; not bound by findings.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 311 Constitution; precedents like Khem Chand v. Union of India

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court cannot interfere if government acted bona fide, even if conclusion based on no evidence; perverse findings only attackable as mala fides.
There is evidence to support charge 3; reasonable view possible in anti-corruption drive.

respondent_arguments.text: Government bound by enquiry officer's findings in favour; cannot differ.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Article 311 Constitution; observations in I.M. Lal and Khem Chand

respondent_arguments.text: Government's conclusion on misconduct not supported by any evidence; perverse.

court_reasoning.text: Government entitled to consider report and evidence, agree or differ wholly/partially; if differs when findings favour servant, issue second notice with proposed punishment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Enquiry officer is delegate; findings not binding on government.

court_reasoning.text: High Court under Art 226 can examine if conclusion supported by any evidence; no need for mala fides if no evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Test: If whole evidence accepted true, does conclusion follow? No weighing evidence.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence for charge 3: Rajagopalan admitted not offered bribe, note folded, eyesight imperfect; respondent's version papers for letter; suspicion not proof.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere suspicion cannot replace proof even in domestic enquiries.

holdings.text: Government competent to differ from enquiry officer's findings of fact.
High Court can quash if conclusion not supported by any evidence, without proving mala fides.
Charge 3 not proved by any evidence; dismissal unsustainable.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Secretary of State for India v. I. M. Lal
precedents_cited.relevance: Scope of s.240 Government of India Act 1935; second notice based on enquiry results.

precedents_cited.case_name: High Commissioner for India v. I. M. Lal
Khem Chand v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Second opportunity under Art 311; charges proved refer to material, not binding findings.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Assam v. Bimal Kumar Pandit
precedents_cited.relevance: Government may accept some findings, reject others; second notice must specify grounds.

precedents_cited.case_name: A. D'Silva v. Union of India

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction to check no evidence; safeguards for public servants - two notices, natural justice.

statutes_cited.name: Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Departmental enquiry procedure; penalties; conduct violation.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; appellant succeeds on competence to differ from enquiry officer but fails on merits as no evidence supports finding on charge 3; High Court order upheld, dismissal set aside.
outcome.relief_granted: Dismissal quashed; respondent entitled to reinstatement and consequential reliefs.

key_quotes.text: the Government is entitled to consider the report and the evidence led against the delinquent public servant. The Government may agree with the report or may differ, either wholly or partially, from the conclusions recorded in the report.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on government's power to differ from enquiry officer.

key_quotes.text: mere suspicion should not be allowed to take the place of proof even in domestic enquiries.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason for quashing dismissal; no evidence for bribe.

key_quotes.text: if the whole of the evidence led in the enquiry is accepted as true, does the conclusion follow that the charge in question is proved against the respondent?
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for High Court under Art 226 on no evidence.
